WRITING.TEXT: London is lovely - enjoy it! For what it's worth, when I was in London a few summers ago, I was there for almost 2 weeks, walked pretty much everywhere and ate maybe 2 regular sized meals per day. At the end of 2 weeks, I was only up 3 pounds and it was really just water weight because I lost it after restricting for just a few days.

I don't know if you're in the US but I find these really thin flavored crackers that are like, 9 crackers for 50 calories. I can't recall the brand but if I remember I'll let you know! I used to buy them in a Rosemary flavor and they were delicious.

As others said - dressing well and accessorizing yourself to look older, mature and elegant. Also, getting your nails done! I get a full set with gel and it definitely helps me look and feel more mature. I try to stick to neutral nudes and pinks, occasionally getting a pastel color, to look more "adult" (I'm 23 but I'm 5"1 as well so I feel your pain). Funky designs look more juvenile IMO. Also, since it's nearly summer, having a nice pedicure (I usually go for French or nudes/pinks) makes you look like you're older, put together and like you take care of yourself.
Oh haha I don't use the extra oil to cook my eggs. I use non-stick cooking spray on the pan. And I dab the cooked bacon in a paper towel to get rid of the grease that drips off.

The bacon I buy is 80 cals for 2 strips which really isn't that bad, because if I cook a few egg whites with it, it's a normal looking breakfast for like 150 calories. Plus it's all fat and protein so it keeps me full and doesn't bloat me up! Most pre-cooked bacons are even lower in calories.

1. Halo Top, egg whites, thin sliced bagels w whipped cream cheese, Greek yoghurt, bacon (ikr??), granola bars, coffee, Skinny Pop
2. Horseback riding because it's really the only exercise I have the energy to do when I'm restricting.
3. Black Swan, Titanic, Love Actually, Across the Universe, the Harry Potter series, the Twilight series (I know, I know).
4. I honestly don't read much but when I do, it's non-fiction (biographies specifically).
5. Weighing everything

Thank you for your response! I typically don't need to add salt to anything, as long as it's already salted, so it's driving me i n s a n e that I'm consuming so much salt - it's really bloating me even though I'm eating sub 600 calories a day.
Yeah this is super common. Even if I'm not clinically underweight, if I've been restricting for a while, I will get my period then get it again 2 weeks later.

Oh my god yes. All the time. Last year when I was relapsing I lived alone and it was glorious. I only had safe foods in my house, there was nothing and no one to tempt me with things, I was free to weigh myself and my food as I pleased. Ughhh.
After I was discharged from treatment last summer, I started living with my SO (who also has an ED). I have to be extra discrete about my behaviors and it's hard to get away with certain things. It sucks because I often have thoughts "If I didn't live with her, I would have lost xx pounds by now." I have these intrusive thoughts about breaking up with her just so I can be alone and lose weight again. But yeah, living with her makes me realize how I took living alone for granted.

Thanks! I emailed my psychiatrist about it yesterday and am yet to hear back from her. I definitely felt nausea and dizziness around the time I had the metallic taste in my mouth - thankfully it's subsided.

It's a horse riding competition. And yeah being unable to taste flavors and stuff sounds like a dream but on the weeks of competitions I eat more so my performance doesn't suffer. If this weren't a competition week, I probably wouldn't care.

WRITING.TITLE: Not quite ED related, but who has experience with Prozac?
WRITING.TEXT: [removed]
Yep! I was on I think the one that was called pro anorexia? And then in 2011/2012 I belonged to one called anorexic queen (I think).

I'm 5"1 as well and even if I were in the high 60's, I feel like I'd be on my deathbed.
I was in treatment with her in June/July of last year. She didn't really accept recovery at all. Her brain is too far gone to do much. Her family sent her away really in hopes to just keep her alive at the bare minimum. Her family had power of attorney over her so the feeding tube wasn't her choice - it was forced upon her.

She was really lovely when she had moments of clarity but her eating disorder and extreme weight loss literally ate at her brain, so most of the time she was just...batshit crazy. I don't mean that as a judgement but she was just *so sick*.
To the Bone :)
WTF "ana girl" is still a thing? I honestly hate the term pro ana.
Same (with the BPD) and I hate myself so much and I know it's wrong for me to lash out. Lashing out is not okay. Having a mental illness is no excuse for being an asshole.
Carbs will help fuel your workouts and protein is absolutely necessary to help your muscles recover afterwards. It's especially important when you're eating so few calories.

Last I heard this girl had to be transferred to a psychiatric hospital because she was too far gone. She posts on Facebook sometimes and with her selfies she literally, seriously asks if the feeding tube makes her face look fat. It's really sad and it's kind of a wake up call for me....sometimes.

And people who give "advice" there give SERIOUSLY dangerous advice. This one person replied to an anon saying "if your BMI isn't too low you won't have any ill long-term effects from restricting" (in so many words). Like no you can still die from malnutrition if you're of a normal weight lmao
Omg yes. I see those on Pinterest, too.

Also the
"I'm x metres/feet tall, x years old and I weigh x lbs/kg. What should my goal weight be?"

I don't exercise when I restrict, other than horseback riding. I don't have the energy to do any other type of exercise. When I ride I make sure I eat a decent amount of carbs ~20 minutes before. 300 is probably too low to be exercising. Even on days I ride I eat up to 500. Take things slow and see how your body feels. If you feel dizzy/lightheaded or if your chest hurts, you should stop. Also, hydration is super important when you're working out. Especially if you're eating so little.

I agree completely. I follow a lot of BPD blogs as well and there are so many people who follow the mental illness community on tumblr that are just so...entitled? I see a lot of people making fun of neurotypicals (also a new term to me) and it's just like...idk. Entitled and no self awareness, taking no accountability for their own actions and not accepting that they are doing things that are wrong. It's not right and makes their illnesses worse. And then all of the self-diagnosing irks me, too, especially by teenagers. I'm not saying that these teenagers don't have issues but a lot of things they go through are just part of being a teenager, and don't necessarily mean there is a diagnosis.
I hope this doesn't make me sound like a bitch.
Oh yeah I remember Xanga! I used Livejournal the most from 2008-2012 ha. And all the YouTube thinspo videos that all used that one song by Superchick.
Laughable.

But still carry that "celery has negative calories!"
Ah, yes. I, too, thought I was burning more calories eating celery than the calories in celery itself, circa 2008!

WRITING.TITLE: Tumblr is weird.
WRITING.TEXT:
So I was on tumblr a lot from 2011 until 2015 (when I deleted). I didn't follow the pro ED or thinspo community back then very much because I had a comedy blog that was really popular with ~30k followers to keep up with. But I did check up on it on occasion since I did actively restrict and relapse and engage in ED behaviors. Less than 2 weeks ago I decided to give tumblr another go. I created a blog for aesthetics, recovery related stuffy and comedy stuff.
But then I created a secondary blog for thinspo and ED thoughts and feels because I'm not *that* dedicated to recovery. I had no idea how active the pro ED side of tumblr grew *so* much. And it's all kinda...weird? I don't know how to describe how it makes me feel. Sweetspo? Meanspo? I've explored online pro ED communities for almost 10 years now and these terms are all so new to me and somehow don't sit well with me. And then I see all these posts saying "never skip breakfast because eating breakfast speeds up your metabolism". Maybe because I spent the last year on *Reddit's* proED, but eating breakfast is such a weird concept for me? If anything eating breakfast sets myself, and many others (on this sub) up for failure. Personally, I'm better off fasting as long as I can and not eating until like 3pm or so. Even eating a piece of fruit or something for breakfast would ruin my whole day because it makes my hunger cues come back. Putting off eating does cause hunger, yeah, but it's more tolerable and the hunger cues come and go.
IDK the tumblr ED community just seems foreign to me. I guess maybe because it's a lot of teenagers who use it, the ED "advice" there is just so misinformed because these are teens who are uneducated about nutrition. There are also popular ED blogs with thousands of followers and the people who run those blogs give out the WORST nutritional advice. I mean, obviously any advice that encourages ED behaviors, but shit like that would get down voted to hell on this sub.
Anyways, I just needed to rant. I'm just going to try to ignore all the crappy ED stuff on tumblr.

Yeah this girl was 23, 5"9 at around 67 pounds. Her parents had power of attorney over her and funeral arrangements planned already...I can't even comprehend, which is really shitty of me to say considering I was in treatment with her, too.

Your first impression is correct - it was to make them gain weight. These women were severely underweight (BMI's as low as 9, up to 16). They didn't have a diagnosis or symptoms which are traditionally treated with antipsychotics.

Wow I was always under the impression that antipsychotics increased a person's appetite, resulting in weight gain. This actually makes a lot of sense now that I think about it because when I was at treatment, all the women who were severely severely underweight were on antipsychotics.

I'm the exact same way as you. No weight/appetite effects from Prozac or BC. Although I'm almost certain when I went back on Prozac last year, it surpassed my appetite for the first two weeks. But I was already restricting a lot by that point so maybe my hunger cues were already gone. Regarding antipsychotics, literally everyone I know has gained weight on antipsychotics. What is it about those meds that increases ghrelin? Or added ghrelin even? Idk if that's even a thing. Makes me wonder.

I never paid attention to this until I went to treatment, but I've noticed that people with eating disorders tend to look younger than they are. I can't really comment on weight because there were people who were bulimic of normal weight, anorexics who were underweight, atypical anorexics who were barely underweight/still normal weight, etc. But it was weird. There were women there who were in their late 20's and early 30's who looked like they were still in college.

Have people here found that they were better able to control themselves once they moved out of home?
Yes.
Last year I relapsed so hard because it was the first time in my life I wasn't living with my parents or an SO, or had *any* sort of SO/love interest in my life. I was totally on my own. That made it **so** much easier to not eat. I remember having a full 30 day period of restricting. The only time I couldn't restrict was when my mom visited, when I went on a vacation with her and her fianc, and when I had a competition weekend. And once when I bit the bullet and decided to have dinner with my friends.
Now that I have an SO again and am living with them, I almost regret being in a relationship.
~cue nervous laughing that turns into crying~
I was depressed and lonely last year when I was restricting. But I'm still depressed now and at least then I was getting skinny with no interruption. I took for granted how nice it was to buy "rexic foods" (as my SO calls them) and to only have those foods in my fridge in pantry. It's hard living with your SO, having to eat certain foods when they want to eat it. Having to fucking cook spaghetti for them while you're sitting there eating egg whites and a low carb tortilla. Ugh. I can't even body check without my SO saying "can u not". It doesn't help that she also has an ED. And then last night she suggested we go to Sonic for ice cream slushes. Luckily she forgot about her "date" idea.
The only thing I can say is that if someone invites you out to do something, and that something involves food, try your best to go. I know how hard it is to eat at a restaurant or eat anything that doesn't have the calories listed. But for your own sanity, get out of the house a few times a month and be social and try to eat. When I relapsed last year, I didn't see my friends at ALL because I didn't want to eat and it just made things worse.

When I was relapsing last year, I fasted every Monday, allowed 300 calories on inactive days and 500 calories on active days (horse riding). So, on average, I was eating 370 calories a day. I was typically losing 3.5 pounds per week doing this. Sometimes a pound or so more if I did an extra fasting day or ate closer to 300 on an active day. Being short sucks. A month or so into restricting back then, I was fine eating closer to 350 every day. The most I ever ate back then was like 700 calories and that was because I had ridden 3 horses that day.
Now I just try to stay under 500 calories regardless of my activity level for the day. I'm heavier now so the energy balance is probably the same.

Chocolate chips are amazing. Sometimes I eat a cup of plain Cheerios with a cup of unsweetened almond milk. I add a tablespoon of chocolate chips to it and it comes out to less than 200 calories. Slightly calorie dense, yes, but worth it if I need to satisfy my chocolate cravings.

Thanks! You are so sweet. My exam wasn't too bad. My SO is on Wellbutrin and she says it helps her a lot with her depression, I'm glad to hear it's also working for you! I was first put on Prozac when I was 16 (I'm 23 now) and since then I've been on and off it a lot. Same with the Lamictal but since I was 14. Both have worked wonderfully in the past so I'm glad I've started them again. Hopefully in the next month I feel happier.
Are you exercising/doing resistance training?

I was barely underweight when I went to treatment last year. My insurance cut me off as soon as I was at a weight which they deemed healthy, which only took like 3 weeks to reach. 6 weeks into treatment and they cut me off for good. This meant I didn't get to finish the program and I really needed a LOT more help. I *really* wanted to recover, but my insurance cutting me off because I was "healthy enough" was such a turn off. I felt like such a failure. I honestly just want to be sick enough and thin enough to be able to spend enough time in treatment to actually recover. Sigh.

Today is really only day 2 for me but it's going fairly well. I ended yesterday at 360 calories. I started Prozac and Lamictal again (because I've been horribly depressed, yay) today after being off meds since basically August. The Lamictal makes me horribly nauseous. It's 1pm and all I've been able to hold down is 4 club crackers (70). Today is going to be carb heavy because I have an exam in a few hours and I need the energy to focus. I'll probably just be living off more club crackers, strawberries and applesauce today. Maybe some greek yoghurt if I can manage. My SO is blind weighing me once a week. Hopefully come my Sunday weigh in I'm a few pounds lighter. Although she's not going to tell me exactly how much lighter.
Has anyone seen her new ED movie? It was released at Sundance IIRC but I haven't seen anything about a national or world wide release.
I've missed you, too! I hope you are doing well 3

^ this is very important. I'm OP's height and most I've been able to lose in a *week* is an average of 3.5 pounds, and I was eating 370 cals/day on average to achieve that. Not to mention, the lower your weight is, the slower the loss is.
I just followed you from my main blog (hashtag-nourished), but my thinspo blog is thetinyrider :)

I have two tumblrs. My main one is more recovery leaning, with aesthetic things and funny posts (hashtag-nourished). My secondary blog is thinspo and ED things - [thetinyrider](https://thetinyrider.tumblr.com). So you'll end up getting a follow from hashtag-nourished but my thinspo one is thetinyrider!

For me, it's because when I'm thin, it's one less thing to worry about. When I'm restricting, I find that I have a lot more time on my hands because I'm not eating and I'm not socializing. That gives me more time to experiment with my hair and make up so it compliments my shrinking body. If my hair and makeup are on point, and I'm thin, then whenever someone spontaneously asks me to do something with them, I can throw whatever on and *still* look good. I won't look like a fat slob. I can fully enjoy whatever activity it is, knowing I look good doing it and not worrying about my appearance. Whether it's grocery shopping alone or going to a party. I feel confident and comfortable. Even if my hair and makeup aren't done that day, I know I'll still look decent because my body looks good in whatever I'm wearing.
Another part of it is that I'm *horrible* at expressing my emotions. So I show my emotions with my body. If I'm going through something, my small body, extreme weight loss and lack of eating show people that I'm not okay. For me, it's easier to show that physically than with words.

Weighing myself is definitely one of those doors. Once I start weighing myself, my whole life becomes about calories and the number on the scale. If I'm not weighing myself, yeah, I restrict and count calories, but it isn't *as* obsessive because I know that as long I'm at a deficit, I *will* lose. And since my SO is only going to weigh me once a week, I'm not going to obsess about calories as much since I'm not looking at my weight on a daily difference - if that makes sense.
Thank you so much for your reply. It was really helpful!

Once you start feeding your body the food it needs, your hunger cues come back. For me, it takes about a month of pretty consistent restriction for the huger cues to go away. I'm sure if you repeat what you did initially, you'd be able to get rid of the hunger cues again. And starting higher and gradually reducing your calories will help, too. I typically start at 700 and eventually 300-400 is enough.

I feel ya, I can be the same way sometimes. What helps me is set goals, but like, *beyond* realistic goals. Say I'm averaging @ 500 calories a day, I set my goal to be 10 pounds gone in one month. I'd definitely lose that and then some. That way I still feel like I'm working towards a goal, even though it's setting the bar kinda low.

So it works well for you then? You don't feel like it's arbitrary and your ED will take over regardless? That's a fear I have about the thing I'm doing with my SO - that eventually my ED voice will tune everything out and I won't be able to stop, despite having a deal with my SO.

This has been going on probably since November, but it's been more prominent since January. I'm still in regular therapy and I convey all these feelings to my therapist and psychiatrist. So I guess yeah, recovery is an open door for me right now. But I don't want to walk through that door. Everyday I take one step closer to the ED door. But I think you're making a very wise suggestion for me to not weigh myself. Thank you 3
I was a 32DD at my LW last year and I looked like I was a B cup. Maybe your cup size will stay high but as your body changes, they'll look smaller?

I feel like I should just get it over with, know the number and move forward. But I'm just so scared to feel shittier and more depressed than I already do. Because I know no matter what the number is, it probably won't be low enough.

I tell myself I'm in limbo between choosing recovery and choosing my ED but honestly I don't know. I wouldn't say I'm in a full on relapse because when I do have to eat, whether it's with my SO or out to lunch with a friend, I'm able to eat without hesitation for the most part. But I feel awful about it after. I just don't care about recovery anymore.

WRITING.TITLE: My SO weighed me and she won't tell me the number.
WRITING.TEXT:
I've been complaining to my SO a lot lately how I hate my body, want to fit into my dresses I bought when I was underweight before I went to treatment last year, etc. She also has an ED fyi. Anyways, she said she would support me in my weight loss goals as long as I didn't go below a certain number (118) and didn't eat less than 1000 calories a day....
So she weighed me yesterday and said "it's really not anywhere near as bad as you think" and that I could probably get down to 118-120 in a month. I honestly don't know what this means for me because she has such little knowledge about how calories work, TDEE, etc. Also she is almost half a foot taller than me so what may work for her might not be applicable for me.
We have a scale at home and, as much as I want to know the number, I'm too scared to weigh myself even if I'm home alone (which I am right now). If I had to guess I'd say maybe I'm 135? Great. That's where I started when I relapsed last year and by this time last year, I was in the lower 120's.
Anyways, there's now way in hell I'm going to eat max 1000 calories, nor am I going to weight 118 at the least. The most I ever eat when I'm restricting is 500. Maybe 700 if I was more active than usual. And at 118 I don't look nearly skinny enough. I need to be under 110 to be happy. Ugh. I feel like I've fucked it all up my letting her weigh me.
Sigh. There's really no point to this post. Other than the fact I'm more motivated than ever to lose weight.

Lately I've been feeling this so much, but mainly about the past. Like, last spring I was the thinnest I'd ever been as an adult. But I fucked it all up by going to treatment. Yeah...prior to going to treatment I was miserable, lonely, drowning in my anxiety, isolated, depressed, physically in pain, etc. but...at least I was thin :/

When you severely restrict your intake, it's really really hard to prevent muscle loss. It's pretty much a given that you'll lose quite a bit of muscle mass, especially if your restriction is long-term. How many calories are you eating daily? The best thing you could do is probably eat hella hella protein.
This makes sense. Thank you! Just wanted to make sure I'm getting adequate caffeine, should I try this.

Yes, keto ;) I never thought keto would be possible with low cal restriction but I intermittently fast most days so I have a small meal sometime in the afternoon and the last time I eat will be around 6pm or 7pm, so I don't go to bed too hungry. Plus keto is filling, so even though fats are calorie dense, I don't actually use enough to break my calorie goal for the day. I hate feeling hungry - I'd much rather be tired and lethargic than a hangry bitch.

I make these relatively low-cal low-carb breakfast burritos and I've been eating them every morning since Saturday and they're just amazing.
The tortilla is low carb and pretty large. It's 90 calories and only has 6g net carbs. These tortillas actually taste so good and don't taste like cardboard like most other low-carb tortillas/wraps do. Then I scramble 1 egg+2 egg whites. I also add 2 strips of bacon. It comes to 274 calories and fills me up for like 5 hours.
I could eat this every day and even if I weren't restricting, I'd probably still eat it. Although I'd probably use 2 eggs instead of 1+2 egg whites because the texture of scrambled egg whites can be off putting after a while.

Wow this makes me feel so much better about my blob-like physique since going to treatment and becoming weight restored. I needed to read this!
Also IDK if you remember me from like, spring of last year but your user name looks really familiar and I think we'd comment together quite frequently back then! So...hi!!!

Question: is it still effective if your coffee has a little bit of creamer in it? I usually put 2 tablespoons of sugar free creamer in my coffee. I was just wondering if having creamer dilutes the caffeine content in any way, therefore making the bronkaid+coffee combo ineffective.

if you restrict heavily and longer term, it will get to a point where even eating primarily carbs within your too-low calorie limit wont help much and you'll need to increase calories to feel better
Exactly this. When I restrict I try to eat protein and fats the most, honestly. Eggs, string cheese, yoghurt, protein shakes, etc. That way when I *really* need the energy, carbs are amazingly effective.

Ugh they are the worst. I remember one day I ate less than 300 calories and woke up the same weight as the day before. What I do when that happens is coffee fast for a day. When I do this, I allow myself as much coffee as I want in a given day, with a splash of creamer and some stevia. 100% of the time the scale will budge the following day.
I agree 100% with /u/paytontanner94. Also, after a few weeks to a month of consistent restriction, your hunger cues will pretty much disappear completely.

I've definitely been slightly dehydrated and have been trying to up my water intake for the last 2 days which seems to be helping! And I'm kinda also doing keto this week since it's helped me with bloating in the past. Hopefully I'm less bloated by the end of the week!

I'm a competitive equestrian athlete so I ride twice a week, sometimes more, but as of late it's been twice a week. For the past 4-6 weeks I've also been going to the gym 3-4 times a week doing weight lifting and some body weight training. I can't seem to get past the bloating phase of starting a new resistance training routine, so I'm honestly considering quitting the gym because I cannot stand it. Plus I'm starting to restrict more heavily so I won't have much energy to go to the gym anyways.

Yep this was me last night. I was so tired because I only got 4 hours of sleep the night before (which wasn't from restricting, I just couldn't sleep) but couldn't sleep. I restricted to 410 calories yesterday and I exercised for an hour and a half. I could not sleep for a few hours and then I woke up like 3 hours later than I intended to. In my experience it goes away after a couple of weeks. And then after a month or so of consistent restriction, my hunger cues have gone away all together. It also depends on your hydration levels. I've been pretty dehydrated lately (drinking water while restricting makes me really nauseous), but whenever I do push myself to get in eat least 90 oz in a day, I find that I'm able to sleep better.
My trainer said I shouldn't be experiencing water weight this far into my training :/ so I don't know. I'm honestly thinking of quitting it and just continue restricting without the exercise.

I've been going to the gym 2-3 times a week while on a deficit, and I also work with a personal trainer once a week. So 3-4 times in the gym a week, and 2 days of horse riding a week. I've been going to the gym consistently for like 4 weeks now and I'm *so* bloated. I don't understand it. The bloat is everywhere and I just can't deal anymore. It makes my restricting seem and feel pointless :(
This is exactly me!

Honestly, in the past, there would be times where I'd flat out refuse to see my friends because I didn't want to eat. But that isn't sound advice.
In the grand scheme of things, 1 meal isn't *that* bad. I mean, if you fast all day and make smart choices at your meal with friends, you won't necessarily have to go over 800 calories. 800 calories for a day is still a deficit and you'll still lose weight. If you see the scale go up the next day, it's probably just sodium/water retention. These days if I have to go out with friends or my SO to eat, I make sure my meal with them is all I eat that day and that I get at least 30 minutes of exercise beforehand.
Seconding nut bars! I really like Kind Bars - the nuts and spices ones in particular. They are fibrous, contain healthy fats and some protein. Plus if I'm craving sweets they really hit the spot.

I refuse to train my lower body much because i dont want them to get bigger, and they are plenty defined enough.
This was me when I was restricting last year. I stopped going to the gym all together because I didn't want to deal with the stuffed sausage phase, even if it would be temporary.

In the winter it's not *that* bad because skinny jeans + tall boots can make our thighs look slimmer. In the summer, I tend to wear skater dresses that cling to my tiny waist and upper body, and since I'm short, the dress reaches a few inches above my knee, so it makes me look small. But the spring and fall suck sometimes :(

WRITING.TITLE: I went shopping today and realized just how disproportionate I am.
WRITING.TEXT:
My girlfriend and I are in a good place again (yay!) so we went shopping. I have a horse riding competition next week and because I've gained hella weight after going to treatment, I needed some new show clothes. Anyways, I bought a pair of breeches that are 2 sizes bigger than I'd normally wear. Then I went to try some shirts. I first tried on a size large because, well, my thighs are bigger so duh my shirt size will be bigger, too, right? NOPE. The large looked ridiculous on me.
While I cried in the fitting room, my girlfriend went to find me other shirts to try on. She came back with a bunch of shirts in XXS. I wanted to kill her. If a size large made me look fat, then why would an XXS make me feel or look any better? Well, somehow the XXS looks way better on me and *actually* fits me well. It's just so fucking annoying how much my thighs carry most of my weight. I hate it.
Even when I was underweight prior to going to treatment I didn't have a thigh gap - just a keyhole gap. My upper body would look emaciated while my thighs looked so big. Ugh if I'm going to be fat, can I at least look proportionate and not ridiculous? Please.
Is anyone else crazily disproportionate?

This is all planned. It's just past noon and I haven't eaten yet:
Snack: Dark chocolate and sea salt Kind Bar (200)
Dinner: 4 oz chicken breast (120), 1 cup steamed broccoli (30), 1/2 cup brown rice (110), 1 teaspoon light margarine (13) = 273
Exercise: 5 min cardio warmup, 30 min weight lifting = 100 calories burned?? I have no idea.
Total: 373 to 473

Chicken breast
Brown rice
Steamable veggies
Kind bars (although I order those off Amazon monthly)
Protein powder (also bought monthly off Amazon)
Eggs
Fage or Chobani Greek yog
SOON I'll be going back to Almond milk, but right now I'm finishing up a few bottles of soy milk I have at home
Great Value (Walmart) 0 calorie pink lemonade...seriously you guys this shit is SO good and tastes way better than 0 cal Crystal Light. This stuff actually tastes like real lemonade (well, almost haha). It comes in a 2 liter bottle and it's only like $0.87 a bottle where I live. It has *some* calories. Like, they sell it in cans and each can is 5 calories. But still, if I were to drink an entire 2 liter it's like 50 calories for the whole bottle...probably.
Thin sliced bagels
Low fat cream cheese
Morningstar Farms vegetarian sausage patties (I'm usually buy these every 3-4 months in bulk at Costco)
100 calorie Chewy granola bars
Fibre One bars
Bacon
90 calorie Flat Out wraps
Skinny Pop
Halo Top
Where all I consume is coffee all day. I allow myself a splash of creamer with every cup and a packet or two of stevia. 5 cups is the max amount I can handle in a day tbh because of the acidity.

Yes.
When I was in treatment I gained weight rapidly and it distributed so strangely, because it was rapid weight gain. Even when I weighed heavier without being "forced" to gain weight through recovery, I didn't have fat in weird placed like I did compared to having to be weight restored. It's totally normal and it will even out eventually.

Is it possible that fasting is too aggressive for you? Maybe starting at higher cal restriction and working yourself down might help you instead of going straight from bingeing to fasting. That's what helps me at least.
I'm trying. We're trying. We got into a big fight about it last night and haven't really spoken since. It's certainly awkward...

WRITING.TITLE: I'm giving up on recovery because it seems as though my girlfriend has, too.
WRITING.TEXT:
Some of you may not remember me since I haven't been posting on this sub as frequently since I got out of treatment for my ED in the summer. But I've posted before about my live-in girlfriend who also has an eating disorder.
I've had small periods of restriction since getting out of treatment and it would always hurt my girlfriend's feelings when I did. So I would stop. But for the past month or so I've been trying to lose weight the "healthy way" to appease my girlfriend. I've been eating probably 800-1200 calories on any given day and getting exercise 5 out of 7 days a week. I don't weigh myself but my clothes are a little looser. Would I love to go back to restricting to lose weight and be bony and feel happy and in control of my life? Sure. But my girlfriend doesn't allow it.
She's unhappy with her weight and ignores all my attempts to help her lose weight in a healthy manner, as *I've* been doing for the sake of our relationship. But she doesn't want to. She doesn't want slow weight loss. She wants to lose "40 pounds in 40 days" (let's be real, even with restriction that wouldn't happen unless she was morbidly obese, which she isn't). So, as of today, she's stopped eating. She's had a few grapes and like 3 pickles.
This is a big slap in the face to me. What a hypocrite. I can't get myself to break up with her but I guess *both* of us restricting is going to lead to that. So basically, I should care about our relationship and not restrict, but for some reason she's allowed to restrict, not give a shit about our relationship, not care about my recovery and expect me not to restrict AND stay in this relationship?
I'm so angry and I'm so hurt and I know what I'm doing is so passive aggressive but I can't help but feel betrayed and invalidated.
Sigh.

Late to this post and I don't have a drug addiction or substance abuse problem but when I was in treatment, I met a LOT of women who had the two. For them, if they weren't doing drugs or if they were clean, they'd engage in their eating disorder. A lot of them were bulimics and/or binge eaters. And if they weren't engaging in their eating disorder, they were doing drugs. A lot of the time they would go to ED treatment and then drug rehab, or drug rehab followed by ED. A lot of them didn't know they had an ED until they went to drug rehab and were ultimately sent to ED treatment from the rehab. I noticed when they were in ED treatment, they were more dedicated to their drug rehabilitation than they were to their eating disorder rehabilitation.
This is all anecdotal and again, I don't have a substance abuse problem so take it with a grain of salt.

I'm not restricting like I used to before I went to treatment, but I loved my rules from back then and miss it so much:
Wake up, use the toilet (pee and pass a BM if possible), strip naked and weigh myself.
If my weight is higher or the same as the day before, I coffee fast all day/as many days as it takes for my weight to drop (usually 1 day of coffee fasting is enough and I'm allowed as much coffee as I want with a splash of creamer and a packet or two of stevia per cup)
If my weight hasn't stalled nor is it higher and I'm INACTIVE for the day, I fast until 3pm or so and limit to 300 calories
Whether I'm inactive or not, I stop eating at around 6pm or 7pm (I don't remember tbh)
Cut off all liquids at 8pm, my last liquid would be some Sparkling Ice Water with a serving of Miralax and also taking a diuretic pill
On active days, I'm allowed 500 calories but try to stay at/under 400
I body check after every shower, and I shower at night even if I've already showered in the morning in order to pass time and do another body check
Every Monday is a coffee fast day
No liquid calories besides coffee

Have you ever tried whipped butter? A tablespoon is 50 calories. I used to use cooking sprays but it bothered me how I'd never truly know how many calories I'm spraying on the pan when cooking egg whites. But half a tablespoon is plenty to cook 4 egg whites and only comes in at 25 calories.

Carb crash is real. That's why I've given up on fruit smoothies for breakfast and stick to a fattier, higher protein breakfast. 2 strips of bacon + 4 egg whites = less than 150 cals for a breakfast that keeps me full for at least 4 hours. The only times I eat carbs first thing is if I'm riding my horse in the morning and feel weak upon waking up. Generally I don't eat breakfast but if my SO is cooking in the morning and asks me to eat with her, then that's what I *will* have.

My go-to meal around my SO is 2 egg whites (34) a black bean burger patty (110) and 2 strips of bacon (80). Sometimes I'll add a cup of broccoli (30) to make it look bulkier. So that's 224-254 calories. My plate is full and my SO thinks I'm eating a proper dinner.

WRITING.TITLE: How can I mentally/emotionally prepare for weighing myself for the first time in a long time?
WRITING.TEXT:
I had to gain 10 pounds while I was in treatment. 4-6 weeks after being discharged, I weighed myself and was 9 pounds heavier than I was when I left treatment - I'm sure a few of those pounds was water/food from the day weight. Plus I was fully clothed. That was at the end of August/early September.
I know I've gained probably at least 15 pounds since then. Actually, I have no idea. I feel like I haven't been as heavy a I currently am in *years*. I don't know what to expect when I get on the scale but I know whatever the number is, I will have a mental breakdown.
If I could restrict without weighing myself, I totally would. But I need to weigh myself because I'm obsessed with numbers and seeing the number go down will show me I *am* making progress even if I can't see/feel it on my body.
What can I do to help reduce the emotional turmoil of getting on the scale? I feel like such garbage. I know for sure I'm going to fast for at least a day before I weigh myself to get rid of some water weight. But emotionally, is there anything else I can do to make this a less painful experience?
**Edit**: Thank you all for your suggestions! I still haven't weighed myself - still mentally preparing myself. This weight is temporary.

That's happened to me this past week with restricting after eating like a cow for the past ~6 months. I think it just takes some getting used to - our bodies aren't used to our blood sugar being so low and our blood sugar dropping pretty rapidly. The more you do it, the easier it gets. The month or so before I went to treatment last summer, I didn't even have hunger cues despite eating 0-300 calories a day.

I always found coffee to be way better at surpassing my appetite and keeping me "full" compared to diet soda and/or water. Just be careful of the coffee poops...they are pretty gross and very frequent because you're having a BM with no food in your system. But I guess the benefit of them is that you flush pretty much everything out.

I haven't been weighing myself since being discharged from treatment but before I went to treatment, I was losing a pretty linear 3-3.5 pounds per week after the flush of water weight I lost from the first 1-2 weeks of initial restricting.

I usually say "just eating less and moving more!" with a fake giggle and it makes people shut up pretty quickly. Once a friend who is an older woman said "Why are you doing this? Are you depressed?" Maybe because of her age/wisdom she could see beyond the surface. But every time people would ask about my weight loss, I really just wanted to say "I'm dying please help me." .

I'm late to posting but
When I was relapsing last year and my weight would stall (even for just one day) despite restricting and weighing and measuring food meticulously, I would coffee fast for 24-36 hours. So I would have up to 5 cups of coffee with Stevia and a few tablespoons of low cal creamer in each cup and the next morning the scale would budge. Maybe try that if you're comfortable with a fast?
Thanks 3 lovely chatting with you today.
Yeah like, I may be able to get skinny again if I didn't have my girlfriend, but then I'd be thin and pretty...but alone.

I...don't know. I mean, my therapist would never condone me eating 600 calories a day, or diet in any way even if it were done healthily and normally. I'm 23 and have had my ED since I was 13/14. In the past, I've always been able to stop and eat normally. But this time last year is when my most recent relapse happened and I ended up in residential treatment because I could not stop on my own. I'm just hoping it doesn't end that way again.
